I went into this series completely blind without any knowledge of what even the heck it was. It was a recommendation since I’m a big Danganronpa fan and I like mystery stories. So I bought it, watched it and well… it’s OK. Think of it as one of those shows that while it starts off really strong it doesn’t actually know where it’s trying to go with its story and that in turn makes the characters feel a little underwhelming.
So let’s start with the good. The art direction is amazing in this show, I loved the scenes when Kobayashi is breaking down the cases andit uses some amazing visuals to go through the process. I also love how other characters are grey, blank silhouettes to show just how Kobayashi’s mind works.   I also dig the soundtrack and I can’t 100% explain why but I just like it. The first episode is a good strong start that does an impressive job of introducing the main characters and the theme for the rest of the show. It’s also kinda sorta completely F****D up but that’s spoiler talk and we don’t want that. 

And now we come to the bad and unfortunately it doesn’t take very long for the cracks and holes and CRATERS to start to form. So the main protagonist is Akechi, a young star detective that… wait a minute… What do you mean he’s not the main guy… The entire plot after the first 2 episodes is about his story… What do you mean Kobayashi is the main protagonist he does nothing productive for 9 episodes. 


Yeah this is what I mean about the story having a bad direction. While they try to make Kobayashi the main character and they start off well, after ep 2 he might as well not actually exist other than to be another obstacle for Akechi to get over while he actually does something productive. I’m pretty sure Akechi gets more screen time as well. It’s like they didn’t think Kobayashi would be a good character to follow so they made him a sidekick and hindrance to a plot that makes no god damn sense by the end. 


The plot, Oh Boy… It makes you think that you’re about to watch a gripping detective drama with complex crimes and difficult cases, but nope it’s just a crappy rehash of Psycho-Pass’s plot. As soon as Twenty Faces comes into the mix we get a bunch of random stuff happening for some reason and so many tragic backstories you become numb to whatever shock value it tries to throw at you. It’s hard to talk about the story without spoilers but just know if you’ve watched Psycho-Pass season 1 you know how this one ends. 


Overall it’s not a terrible series but don’t expect to be blown away by the story. The art and music really hold it up but not enough from causing it to fumble and struggle. I feel like it need a much longer run time to give more depth and context to what was actually happening, 11 Episodes really isn’t enough for a story like this.


P.S. We get it, Kobayashi looks like a girl. You hammered that nail so hard it fell out the other side and stabbed someone in the eye, you don’t need to bring it up every time he’s in a scene it’s trap overkill.

If you want a serious mystery anime then Ranpo Kitan: Game Of Laplace is not for you. It completely fails at the mystery genre, as other reviewers have explained. However when I began watching it I didn't know it was meant to be a mystery anime, and I have completely enjoyed this anime. So I personally would encourage you not to approach this as a mystery anime, but instead as a psychological. This is an unrealistic psychological tragedy with a strange amount of comedy, in my opinion. I think this is why many people haven't enjoyed it- they wanted a proper mystery anime with properlyconstructed mysteries you can solve set in a realistic setting. If you want that too, give up on this anime. But if you enjoy things like Tokyo Ghoul and Death Note then this anime may be for you.


Ranpo Kitan is very stylistic, and accordingly it has a lot of artistic symbolism and a beautiful soundtrack which perfectly fits the mood of the show. The core idea that Ranpo Kitan seems to be trying to portray is that reality seems absurd to us but that's just because we fail to account for the infinite factors influencing us. As a determinist and someone interested in the irrationality of human psychology I found the exploration of this premise very interesting. Since the show is trying to depict reality as something absurd you'll find a lot strange and eccentric characters whose quirks seems pointless. I don't think the quirks are pointless though- I think they are all there to contribute to the idea I outlined above. Why does the new teacher act like an 11 year old and dress like a lolita? You won't find an answer in the show, but that's kind of the point: if we are to believe that all of the past influences all of the future then it'd be silly to think we'd understand our present since we are not omniscient beings who know all of the past.


Oh, plus there's an adorable trap as the main character. I understand many people don't like traps, which respect, so you can think of this as a warning if you're one of those people. But dang, I have weak spot for them.

Another re-interpretation of Ranpo Edogawa's work goes down to the wayside...though not as bad as it seems.
Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace is an anime adaptation of Ranpo Edogawa's work and commemorates his 50th anniversary of his death. So LA had some brushes with Ranpo Edogawa in watching anime, from his superpowered human self in Bungou Stray Dogs to another re-interpretation of his works in Trickster: Edogawa Ranpo "Shounen Tanteidan" yori. with hit and miss respectively. What about Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace?..well...
Let's start off with the plot itself, the plot follows at first small isolated cases but the plot itself has a larger narrative, mainlyof Twenty Faces the main villain of the series, not a person as per say but the concept or deity that protects the weak and kill wrongdoers in society, with Akechi the "genius" detective voiced by Takahiro Sakurai, Kobayashi voiced by Rie Takahashi his assistant and Hashiba voiced by Daiki Yamashita, Kobayashi's best friend in helping Akechi with his cases...that is the bottom line of the anime. Plot wise LA liked many of the isolated cases though brief due to how quickly Kobayashi solves the cases, but it's not until the "true" Twenty Faces gets the spotlight and becomes the main driving force of the anime that LA actually took interest in the anime. Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace's pacing to say the least and how LA frames the plot as a whole, is RUSHED to say the least and no just because the anime was 11 episodes wasn't the point, as they just rush cases left right and center, only properly caring for Twenty Faces case as it's the only complex case in the anime.


Character wise, LA never really got invested in any character, except maybe Twenty Faces himself, mainly due to how much coverage as a character and concept he gotten is the main draw. The main cast of Akechi, Kobayashi and Hashiba however doesn't help as Akechi is the stoic detective archetype, Kobayashi the genki character obsessed with solving mysteries and Hashiba being Kobayashi's minder and all of them really don't change from most of the cases given, maybe Akechi but that's ONLY due to the Twenty Face case having a VERY strong link towards him. The minor cast might as well be red shirt army or the culprit, though LA was wrong a few times.


On speaking of which, since this is a "mystery thriller" anime, it's more of a psychological one than a mystery in all honesty, not only because of the rushed pacing but because most of the isolated cases Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace goes through have the smallest and LA says this very strongly detail becomes the clue to the culprit is. Like a good mystery is one which the audience can project along with the characters to how the culprit is, Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace doesn't give you that opportunity OR it's the most unassuming one that you can't predict at all. Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace is NOT a mystery anime to say the least...and doesn't help even further by Laplace which LA will get into later...


Animation done by Lerche is an ambitious one, having a tinge of SHAFTiness about itself with giving us wacky transitions even bleeding into the "props" of the backgrounding and characters themselves, like showing background characters as shadows or blank dolls. Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace seems rather fascinated with the light switch transition as it's used EXCESSIVELY and likes to play the metaphorical monologues in people's thinking processes (Akechi and Kobayashi using it the most). Though all of this together does make the animation stand out....as much as it started to annoy LA, even though these kind of animation flourishes are meant to draw us in, it oddly did the opposite.


Voice acting was good with no real standout and hello Di- Takehito Koyasu your here as well!. Rie Takahashi as Kobayashi was something of a welcome reprieve as her voice acting helped levitate the dullness of the anime, Takahiro Sakurai's Akechi and Daiki Yamashita's Hashiba not helping matters. With the spectrum of either "genki enthusiastic" voice acting to dull and serene voice acting...LA was fine with the voice cast to say the least.


In all honesty about Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace, it was the imbalance and disconnect of the plot, mysteries and characters that really did it for LA. Individually all good stories but since the main characters are all geniuses and thus stock bland and never improving or changing, the story gets a little tainted as the mystery hardly grows, this includes Twenty Faces even though THAT got a full backstory! Well for Twenty Faces...the main problem with that one is the anticlimax it gave itself, which in turn LA can say for the ALL the cases.


"Laplace" to which the Game the anime has set itself, is one such where a hyper-intelligence can know when, where and why of all particles are in the universe, another words, know what's gonna happen next. Because Akechi and Twenty Faces are highly linked to this, yes makes them utter geniuses, but as a counter, makes things up as it goes along with it's characters which the audience doesn't know with the vaguest of hints as the only through line. It cripples the narrative which not helped by it's bland characters but the mysteries as theatrical and wacky the anime seem to make them it doesn't help when the main characters crushes your rose tinted glasses every single turn.


Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace is no Trickster: Edogawa Ranpo "Shounen Tanteidan" yori as that anime utterly bored LA by BOTH it's annoying characters and dragged out nonsensically theatrical plot, Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace at the VERY least has it's isolated cases being interesting and Twenty Faces' story with a bit of animation pizzazz to keep LA interested...barely.


Maybe having a Laplace demon in the anime itself was the spanner in the works in itself...

Ranpo Kitan in a Nutshell:
Interesting show with a rather dark humor. Has some damn good artistic moments and expressions with some of the scenes that probably went under-appreciated to most viewers . The story is pretty shaky and is simple but doesn't invoke anything to "Wow" about. The story held it back pretty much.
Should you watch?:
Watch it when you're bored. Definitely not a great anime, but far from bad.

Ranpo Kitan Game of Laplace had so much potential. From the get-go, it slams its unique artwork, storytelling style and grasps you with a psychological mystery thriller vibe. As the series goes on, however, the initial chills and salivation for a potentially amazing anime I had was replaced by pure disappointment. If you're thirsting for an anime with a strong plot, I wouldn't recommend Game of Laplace. For general viewing pleasure, go for it.
In the beginning, it was awesome. Sure, some of the "mysteries" were simple, but the episodic feel and pacing felt right. Most of all, with rapid-fire dialogue and a tinge of darkhumor every other conversation, the show was intriguing. The attempt to explore the extent to which human emotion can become twisted was cheesy, but thrilling enough to keep me wanting for more. 


The momentum builds up every episode, and I waited for the turning point, slowly reaching the peak of the roller coaster...


... And it somehow stops, and stays stalled. 


The whole show quickly becomes a mess of plot elements over the last few episodes. Many parts were rushed to the point where it was hurting the story, and the psychological thriller sees a bit of melodramatic teenage angst creeping in. All the elements and potential were there, and it was frustrating to see them thrown in not to make a point, but (my thoughts) just to put it in there before the anime ends. This in itself wasn't too bad, but the problem was in how strong of an impression the first few episodes left me, compared to how mediocre the final 2-3 episodes were.


One thing that this anime does well is with its themes within its artwork. The ominous skull, silhouetted people, spotlights showcasing thought processes: all of it contributed to the overall atmosphere of Game of Laplace. It's easy to tell that it was a somewhat budget anime, but akin to Bakemonogatari, uses its constraints to create something a bit different and interesting. 


The main characters are very unchanging and one-dimensional; by themselves, they're boring as hell. However, most of my enjoyment came in the various interactions between the characters philosophies, rather than the (non-existent) growth of the characters. 


There's a reason why I would and wouldn't recommend this anime: it totally betrays your expectations and settles for a rushed, over-simplified ending. Don't get me wrong, I absolutely LOVED the show. If the plot was done well, I would have it crowned in my top 10 personal anime favorites.

I am not a huge fan of the mystery genre, but what mysteries I have seen, I usually enjoy. Ranp Kitan: Game of Laplace is no different. While everyone seems to be willing to rip this anime to shreds, I believe that it is the type of anime that everyone should at least watch once. You won't come out of it confused or feeling like you wasted time; it's one of those anime that whether you think its lacking or rich, you won't regret watching it.
The anime starts off very interestingly, somewhat reminiscent of Psycho-Pass, with unusual murders, missing persons, and abnormal characters such asShadow Man. I was drawn in within the first 3 episodes with the need to learn more. Kobayashi is our main character, a young, bored little androgynous boy who finds enjoyment out of life in mysteries. I enjoyed watching the mysteries unfold and seeing how the characters figured out the murderers. It's not exactly Sherlock Holmes, but you'll be racking your brain for a bit.\n
The main idea of the anime is to introduce to you several persons who have committed heinous crimes, and then they present the idea that these criminals get off easy due to the insanity plea. Sound familiar, anyone? It reminds me a lot of what is wrong with our own justice system as the story seems to be criticizing the Japanese justice system for making it easy for criminals. After this idea is introduced to the audience, the anime follows other vigilantes until we get to the main part of the plot.\n
The climax of the plot is not all that exciting. They try to put a plot twist inside and then explain the incidents that led up to the present, which adds some depth to the characters, but isn't imperative. The ending isn't all that grand either. It was disappointing to say the least, but I can't deny that I did thoroughly enjoy this anime, which everyone seems to vehemently deny in their reviews.\n
My favorite part of the anime is the overall idea behind it: the justice system is a flawed system, but again, it's nothing new. Even the video game Phoenix Wright toys with this idea. It was just interesting to see everything fall into a state of anarchy similar to Psycho-Pass. My favorite character has to be Kobayashi who really just cracks me up with his silly antics and unusual behavior. Sometimes I find myself wondering if he truly is a boy. I would have liked to learn more about him, truth be told, because while I understand that he's a brilliant young boy who's bored with the world, I'd like to know what exactly caused that. There needs to be more character development!!!\n
Anyway, here's my two cents. Just wanted to say that this anime isn't the worst anime in the world; it's actually worth watching.

This is a terrible anime with the most promising and misguiding first 3 episode. Ever. The beginning is promising, and makes you feel like the show is going to be dark, mysterious, with lots of mystery. but after that, it goes downhill.
 Story: You thought there will be mysterious backstory? Or some mindblowing plot twists?  Well NOPE. The backstory is incredibly stupid, and the plot was so bad, it felt like it was written by a 14 years old boy who learned story writing from Michael Bay and philosophy from Fate/Stay Night. 
 Art: Butterflies. Butterflies everywhere. It was supposed to resemblance the butterflyeffect but instead, it looks like a 9 year old girl's wet dream.\n
 Sound: Actually this is quite nice,  but the lyric sucks, badly.\n
 Character: There's Trap Waifu Bait, Generic Nice Anime Guy, Supposed-to-be-badass-genius-with-shady-past Guy (kinda like Captain Phasma)\n
Overall, 4/10

Overall, I really liked this show and the qualities of it. It was extremely different from the other shows that I had watched so it had an interesting and unique feel.
Story:8/10
The story was great except for a few parts. I really liked how complex, crazy, and unique it was. This actually made me pause and try to figure out what was happening. I really like it when the show is extremely complex because it allows me to think and go over what has happened. At certain parts, the story would be very confusing. Without this complexity, I would have saw it as boring. I wouldalso have forgotten what had happened in the show. The unique story also caught my attention. It was very different from the normal and popular shows that I watch (which has started to bore me). The craziness of the story also really intrigued me. The flow of the story was weird but made sense. Moreover, how the story was able to mix weird comedy, suspense, and darkness together is really good and was shown throughout the show. However every story has its flaws. I didn’t really like the ending because it felt like it ended abruptly. The ending also made me feel a need for a season 2 to clear up some things. This show should also be considered to be more of a thriller than a mystery. It lacks the variables that allow it to be considered a mystery.


Art:8/10

The art style really fitted with the story. However, I was a little bit annoyed by how the unimportant characters were not really “shown.” I understand that there is a reason for this but I don’t really like it.


Sound:8/10

The voices of the characters were really good. The voices of the person “showed” a bit of the person’s character. I also really liked the ending song since it felt calm. However, the opening song didn’t feel correct.


Character:10/10

The mishmash of strange characters were really interesting and unique. It felt like that they didn’t belong in the story. However this feel made the story very interesting and made me want to see how things turned out. The main characters were all really well-rounded with unique abilities and differences. Furthermore, the main protagonist was really intriguing in his thoughts and actions. The villains of the story also had a reason to be there.


Enjoyment:10/10

I really enjoyed how fast pace and unique this story was and I’m currently rewatching it even though I finished it a day ago. I would remember this anime as one of the best if not the best I had ever watched.

First things first. My "reviews" system is explained on a blog entry. Which can be found through my profile.

✦Story
Artistic murder cases being solved by high schoolers. It was unique, but somehow the whole presentation felt so damn boring. As well the cases became eventually quite lame. I'm not sure who to comment story better regarding this anime, all I can say, it was unique, but for some reason really boring.
✦Art&Sound
Unique, and quite nice. Artistic murders quite cool, reminded me of hannibal. Music was also quite satisfying. On top of that those "sad, sweet voice" English songs were also a nice touch.
✦Character
I really liked them, veryeccentric and psychotic. Love those types of characters. Also main guy being labeled as "guy" is moronic. It's literally a female character, but feels like author thought-process went like this, "you know what, right know we have just a bit crazy little girl as a main character, but you know what, let's make a twist, change HER into HIM story-wise". Point being, rather than trap, it simply feels as female character was tagged as male and that's how they rolled.\n\n
✦Enjoyment/overall\n\n
Even though it was unique and odd on quite some elements, it nevertheless felt really boring and lacking..

I am the polar opposite of the community on this one. Ranpo Kitan, in my own opinion, deserves a praise for the work and beauty placed inside of the show. Every episode had so much symbolism, each case showcases the disgusting crimes that we human beings commit on occasion. Ranpo Kitan doesn't make sense because of the simple minded approach that the majority came at it with. The show reflects and mirrors our own, asking our protagonist and antagonist, what is really right? Should we live our lives relying on justice systems incapable of justice, or bring it about through a sense of absolute anarchy?Ranpo Kitan challenges the viewers' attitudes, values, and beliefs with reality and that is why I consider it a masterpiece.\n
